definition:
Let $S_0$ be a Riemann surface. Consider all pairs $(S,f)$ where $S$ is
a Riemann surface and $f$ is a sense-preserving quasiconformal mapping
of $S_0$ onto $S$. We say $(S_1,f_1) \sim (S_2,f_2)$ if $f_2 \circ
f_1^{-1}$ is homotopic to a conformal mapping of $S_1$ onto $S_2$. In
this case we say that $(S_1,f_1)$ and $(S_2,f_2)$ are [*Teichmüller
equivalent*]{}. The space of equivalence classes under this relation is
called the [*Teichmüller space*]{} $T(S_0)$ and $(S_0,I)$ is called the
initial point of $T(S_0)$. The equivalence relation is called
[*Teichmüller equivalence*]{}.

There exists a natural [*Teichmüller metric*]{} on $T(S_0)$, where the
distance between $(S_1,f_1)$ and $(S_2,f_2)$ is $\log K$ where $K$ is
the smallest maximal dilatation of a mapping homotopic to
$f_2 \circ f_1^{-1}$.

There is also a natural isometry between $T(S_0)$ and $T(S_1)$ defined
by a quasiconformal mapping of $S_0$ onto $S_1$. The mapping
$(S,f) \mapsto (S,f \circ g)$ induces an isometric mapping of $T(S_1)$
onto $T(S_0)$. So we could think of $T(\cdot)$ as a contravariant
functor from the category of Riemann surfaces with quasiconformal maps
to the category of Teichmüller spaces (as a subcategory of metric
spaces).
